Improvements in climate and/or technology raise regional productivity and lead to long-run aggregate population growth through Malthusian dynamics.

Regional population growth leads to higher local population densities at individual sites, causing an initial closure of the best sites (insider–outsider inequality) and the subsequent stratification of the best sites (elite–commoner inequality).

Regional population growth leads to higher local population densities at individual sites, causing an initial closure of the best sites (insider–outsider inequality) and the subsequent stratification of the best sites (elite–commoner inequality).
Thus, productivity growth due to improved climate or technology yields greater regional inequality, more inequality at individual stratified sites and worsening absolute poverty for commoners.
